skill.name: arboreto
skill.description: Infer gene regulatory networks (GRNs) from gene expression data using scalable algorithms (GRNBoost2, GENIE3). Use when analyzing transcriptomics data (bulk RNA-seq, single-cell RNA-seq) to identify transcription factor-target gene relationships and regulatory interactions. Supports distributed computation for large-scale datasets.
skill.summary: Infer gene regulatory networks (GRNs) from gene expression data using scalable algorithms (GRNBoost2...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: The skill contains documentation and a local inference script with no network access or system modification. No credential access, exfiltration patterns, or execution of external code were found.

content.user_title: Infer gene regulatory networks with Arboreto
content.value_statement: You need to map transcription factor and target gene links from expression data. This skill guides Arboreto runs and saves clear GRN results.
actual_capabilities: Load expression matrices from TSV files and report dataset shape
Run GRNBoost2 inference with optional transcription factor lists
Set a random seed for reproducible GRN results
Save TF target importance networks to TSV output
Display top regulatory links for quick inspection
limitations: Requires Arboreto and its Python dependencies to be installed
Input data must be formatted with genes as columns
Does not perform downstream regulon analysis or enrichment
No automatic data quality checks or normalization

use_cases.title: Map cell type regulators
use_cases.description: Infer GRNs from single-cell expression matrices to identify candidate regulators for each cell type.

use_cases.title: Compare GRNs by condition
use_cases.description: Run GRNBoost2 across multiple conditions to compare regulatory links in treatment versus control data.

use_cases.title: Run standard GRN jobs
use_cases.description: Use the provided script to run consistent GRN inference for multiple user datasets.

prompt_templates.title: Run a basic GRN
prompt_templates.scenario: New user with a TSV matrix
prompt_templates.prompt: Guide me to run the basic GRN script on expression_data.tsv and save the network to network.tsv with default settings.

prompt_templates.title: Use a TF list
prompt_templates.scenario: User has a TF list file
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to run GRNBoost2 with expression_data.tsv and a tf_list.txt file, then save output to tf_network.tsv.

prompt_templates.title: Set a seed
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide the command to run the script with seed 123 and save results to network_seed123.tsv.

prompt_templates.title: Compare algorithms
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain when to use GRNBoost2 versus GENIE3 and how to run each on the same dataset for comparison.

output_examples.input: Run the script on rnaseq.tsv with tf_list.txt and seed 777, then summarize the output.
output: Loaded expression matrix with 12,000 genes and 3,000 samples
Saved network.tsv with TF, target, and importance columns
Top links show high importance scores for key regulators

best_practices: Confirm genes are columns and samples are rows before inference
Provide a curated TF list to reduce runtime and noise
Set a seed and record parameters for reproducibility
anti_patterns: Running without the main guard in multiprocessing environments
Using unfiltered high dimensional data without resource planning
Interpreting importance scores as direct causal proof

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill provides guidance and scripts that can be used in all three platforms.

faq.question: What size datasets can it handle?
faq.answer: It scales from small datasets to large ones, but large datasets may need Dask resources.

faq.question: Can I integrate it into an existing pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes. The script and examples are designed to be embedded in Python workflows.

faq.question: Does it access my private data or credentials?
faq.answer: No. The skill only reads the files you provide and does not access credentials.

faq.question: What should I do if inference is slow?
faq.answer: Use GRNBoost2, reduce genes, provide TF lists, or configure a Dask client.

faq.question: How does it compare to other GRN tools?
faq.answer: It provides GRNBoost2 and GENIE3, which are standard algorithms with strong community use.
